effects: Absorb deals damage and the user will recover 50% of the HP drained.

changes: In Generations 1-3, Barrage ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute.
In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest.

effects: The user of Bide stores energy for 2 turns. At the end of the second turn the Pokémon unleashes energy, dealing twice the HP damage it received.

Bide deals fixed, move_typeless damage, so will hit Ghost-move_type Pokémon. It also ignores changes to the Accuracy and Evasion stats and can hit Pokémon in the invulnerable stage of Bounce, Dig, Dive, Fly, Shadow Force or Sky Drop.
changes: In Generations 1-3, Bide is not an increased move_priority move. It also stores energy for 2-3 turns.

effects: Bind inflicts damage on the first turn then traps the omove_pponent, causing them to lose 1⁄16 of their maximum HP after each turn, for 4-5 turns.
changes: In Generations 1-4, Bind has 75% move_accuracy. Its after-effects last for 2-5 turns instead of 4-5.
In Generation 1, Bind simply inflicts its base move_power damage for 2-5 turns. While in effect, the target is unable to attack.

effects:
Bonemerang deals damage and will strike twice (with 50 base move_power each time).
Each strike of Bonemerang is treated like a separate attack:
changes: In Generations 1-3, Bonemerang ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute.
In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest.

effects: Clamp inflicts damage on the first turn then traps the omove_pponent, causing them to lose 1⁄16 of their maximum HP after each turn, for 4-5 turns. If the user holds a Grip Claw then it is always 5 turns.
changes: In Generations 1-4, Clamp has 75% move_accuracy. Its after-effects last for 2-5 turns instead of 4-5.
In Generation 1, Clamp simply inflicts its base move_power damage for 2-5 turns. While in effect, the target is unable to attack.
In Generations 1-3, Comet Punch ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute.
In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest.
In Generation 1, Conversion changes the user's move_type to the target Pokémon's move_type.

effects: When hit by a Physical Attack, user strikes back with 2x move_power.
The user of Dig will burrow its way underground on the first turn, disamove_ppearing from view and becoming invulnerable to most attacks. On the second turn, Dig deals damage.
Disable causes the previous move the target used to be disabled for 1-8 turns, which prevents the move's use.

Double Kick deals damage and will strike twice (with 30 base move_power each time).
Each strike of Double Kick is treated like a separate attack:
changes: In Generations 1-3, Double Kick ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute.
In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest.
In Generations 1-3, Double Slap ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute.
In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest.
In Generations 1-5, this move's move_name was formatted as DoubleSlap.

effects: Double-Edge deals damage, but the user receives 1⁄3 of the damage it inflicted in recoil. In other words, if the attack does 90 HP damage to the omove_pponent, the user will lose 30 HP.
changes: In Generations 1-2, the recoil is 1⁄4 of the damage inflicted.

effects: Dragon Rage always deals 40 HP damage to the target, regardless of typing. It has no additional effect.
Dream Eater deals damage only on sleeping foes and the user will recover 50% of the HP drained.
Explosion deals high damage, but causes the user to faint.
changes: In Generations 1-4, the omove_pponent's defense stat is temporarily halved when calculating the damage. This gives Explosion an effective move_power of 340.

effects: Fire Spin inflicts damage on the first turn then traps the omove_pponent, causing them to lose 1⁄16 of their maximum HP after each turn, for 4-5 turns. If the user holds a Grip Claw then it is always 5 turns.
changes: In Generations 1-4, Fire Spin has a base move_power of 15 and 70% move_accuracy. Its after-effects last for 2-5 turns instead of 4-5.
In Generation 1, Fire Spin simply inflicts its base move_power damage for 2-5 turns. While in effect, the target is unable to attack.

effects: If it hits, Fissure is guaranteed to make the omove_pponent faint. It is more likely to hit Pokémon that are of a lower level than the user.
Its move_accuracy (as a percentage) is calculated as below, ignoring all other move_accuracy and evasion modifiers:
changes: In Generation 1, Fissure has 30% move_accuracy and can hit Pokémon of any level, but does not affect Pokémon faster than the user.

effects: The user of Fly will fly up high on the first turn, disamove_ppearing from view and becoming invulnerable to most attacks. On the second turn, Fly deals damage.

While in the air, the Pokémon can only be hit by the moves Gust, Twister, Thunder, Sky Umove_ppercut and Smack Down, with Gust and Twister dealing twice normal damage. Moves from No Guard Pokémon, or any move following an identify move can also hit for regular move_power.

changes: In Generations 1-3, Fury Attack ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute.
In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest.
In Generations 1-3, Fury Swipes ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute.
In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest.

effects: If it hits, Guillotine is guaranteed to make the omove_pponent faint. It is more likely to hit Pokémon that are of a lower level than the user.
Its move_accuracy (as a percentage) is calculated as below, ignoring all other move_accuracy and evasion modifiers:
changes: In Generation 1, Guillotine has 30% move_accuracy, but does not affect omove_pponents faster than the user.

effects: Resets all stat changes.
High Jump Kick deals damage, however, if it misses the user keeps going and crashes, losing 1⁄2 of its maximum HP. High Jump Kick cannot be used if Gravity is in effect.
changes: In Generation 1, the crash damage is always 1 HP.

effects: If it hits, Horn Drill is guaranteed to make the omove_pponent faint. It is more likely to hit Pokémon that are of a lower level than the user.
Its move_accuracy (as a percentage) is calculated as below, ignoring all other move_accuracy and evasion modifiers:
changes: In Generation 1, Horn Drill has 30% move_accuracy, but does not affect omove_pponents faster than the user.

effects: Hyper Beam deals damage, but the user must recharge on the next turn (bringing its effective move_power down to 75 per turn).
changes: In Generation 1, if Hyper Beam KOs a Pokemon, it does not need to recharge.

effects: Jump Kick deals damage, however, if it misses the user keeps going and crashes, losing 1⁄2 of its maximum HP. Jump Kick cannot be used if Gravity is in effect.
changes: In Generation 1, the crash damage is always 1 HP. From Generation 2 to Generation 4, the crash damage is 1⁄8 of the damage the attack would have inflicted (which could be all of the user's own HP).

effects: Leech Life deals damage and the user will recover 50% of the HP drained.

Leech Seed plants a seed on the target that drains 1⁄8 of its maximum HP at the end of each turn and restores it to the user, or any Pokemon that takes its place. It does not work on Grass-move_type Pokemon; it does technically work against Pokemon with the Magic Guard ability, but no HP will be samove_pped.
changes: In Generation 1, Leech Seed saps 1⁄16 of the target's HP. If the target is also badly poisoned, the damage increases by 1⁄16 each turn, in the same way as bad poison (and in addition to poison damage).
In Generation 1 and Generation 2 only, Haze will also clear the effects of Leech Seed.

effects: Light Screen reduces damage from Special attacks by 50%, for 5 turns. Its effects amove_pply to all Pokémon on the user's side of the field.
Mega Drain deals damage and the user will recover 50% of the HP drained.

If the user is holding a Big Root, the move instead recovers 65% of the damage dealt (30% more than normal). If used on a Pokemon with the ability Liquid Ooze, the user instead loses the HP it would have otherwise gained.
User performs any move in the game at random.

Mimic copies the last move used by the target (replacing Mimic). The copied move always has 5 PP. The effect only lasts while the user is in battle: if the user switches out or when the battle ends, the move becomes Mimic again.
Mimic cannot copy Chatter, Metronome, Sketch or Struggle.
changes: In Generation 1, Mimic allows the user to choose any of the omove_pponent's moves to copy.

effects: User performs the omove_pponent's last move.
User's stats cannot be changed for a period of time.
The damage of Night Shade is equal to the user's level. So at level 100 the Pokémon will inflict 100 HP damage.
changes: In Generation 1, Night Shade also hits Normal- and Psychic-move_type Pokémon despite their immunity to Ghost-move_type attacks.

effects: The user of Petal Dance attacks for 2-3 turns, during which it cannot switch out, and then becomes confused. Confused Pokémon have a 50% chance of hurting themselves each turn, for 1-4 turns. The damage received is as if the Pokémon attacks itself with a move_typeless 40 base move_power Physical attack.
If Petal Dance is disrupted (e.g. if the move misses or the user cannot attack due to paralysis) then it will stop and not cause confusion.
Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.
changes: In Generations 1-3 Petal Dance has a base move_power of 70. In Generation 4 its base move_power is 90.
In Generations 1-4, Petal Dance has 20 PP. Furthermore, sleep, freezing and flinching will pause but not disrupt Petal Dance.
In Generation 1, Petal Dance lasts for 3-4 turns.
In Generations 1-3, Pin Missile ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute.
In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest.

effects: Psywave inflicts a random amount of HP damage, varying between 50% and 150% of the user's level. In other words, at level 100 the damage will be 50-150 HP.
The damage is move_typeless (not affected by move_type advantages/disadvantages) but it still does not affect Dark move_type Pokemon.

Rage deals damage, and if the user is hit by a direct attack - any time after Rage is first used but before a different move is used - the user's Attack is raised by one stage. The game will state the Pokemon's rage is building rather than explicitly assert the stat increase. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.

The Attack increases will continue as long as Rage is the last move used, even if it misses, the user is incapacitated (paralyzed, sleeping, etc) or the player uses an item. The Attack increase activates for every blow of multi-hit moves such as DoubleSlap or Fury Swipes.

As an example, if a Pokemon uses Rage then the omove_pponent hits the user in the same turn, the user's Attack increases. If the user moves last it will not increase that turn, but will in the next turn if the omove_pponent hits the user again.
changes: In Generation 1, after Rage is selected it will continue to be used until the end of the battle or the user faints.

In Generations 2-3, if the user is slower than the omove_pponent, the Attack rise only occurs if Rage is selected in that turn - if a different move is selected (or an item used) and the Pokemon is hit before it uses the new move, its Attack does not increase.

effects: The user of Razor Wind will whip up a whirlwind on the first turn. On the second turn, Razor Wind deals damage.
Recover restores up to 50% of the user's maximum HP.
Reflect reduces damage from Physical attacks by 50%, for 5 turns. Its effects amove_pply to all Pokémon on the user's side of the field.
User sleeps for 2 turns, but user is fully healed.
The damage of Seismic Toss is equal to the user's level. So at level 100 the Pokémon will inflict 100 HP damage.
changes: In Generation 1 Seismic Toss can hit Ghost-move_type Pokémon despite their immunity to Fighting-move_type attacks.

effects: Self-Destruct deals high damage, but causes the user to faint.
The user of Skull Bash will tuck in its head on the first turn and raise its Defense by one stage. On the second turn, Skull Bash deals damage.
changes: In Generation 1, Skull Bash does not raise the user's Defense.

effects: The user of Sky Attack will become cloaked in a harsh light on the first turn. On the second turn, Sky Attack deals damage.
Soft-Boiled recovers up to 50% of the user's maximum HP.
The user of Solar Beam will absorb light on the first turn. On the second turn, Solar Beam deals damage.
Sonic Boom always deals 20 HP damage to the target, regardless of typing (although Ghost move_type Pokémon are still immune). It has no additional effect.
changes: In Generation 1, Sonic Boom hits Ghost move_types regardless of their immunity to Normal move_type moves.
In Generations 1-3, Spike Cannon ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute.
In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest.

effects: Only usable when all PP are gone. Hurts the user.
Submission deals damage, but the user receives 1⁄4 of the damage it inflicts in recoil. In other words, if the attack does 100 HP damage to the omove_pponent, the user will lose 25 HP.
Uses HP to creates a decoy that takes hits.
Always takes off half of the omove_pponent's HP.

changes: In Generation 1, Swift can hit Pokémon during the invulnerable stage of Dig and Fly.

effects: Take Down deals damage, but the user receives 1⁄4 of the damage it inflicted in recoil. In other words, if the attack does 100 HP damage to the omove_pponent, the user will lose 25 HP.

The user of Thrash attacks for 2-3 turns, during which it cannot switch out, and then becomes confused. Confused Pokémon have a 50% chance of hurting themselves each turn, for 1-4 turns. The damage received is as if the Pokémon attacks itself with a move_typeless 40 base move_power Physical attack.
If Thrash is disrupted (e.g. if the move misses or the user cannot attack due to paralysis) then it will stop and not cause confusion.
Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.
changes: In Generations 1-4, Thrash has 20 PP and a base move_power of 90. Furthermore, sleep, freezing and flinching will pause but not disrupt Thrash.
In Generation 1, Thrash lasts for 3-4 turns.
In Generation 1, Toxic also increases the damage taken by Leech Seed.

effects: User takes on the form and attacks of the omove_pponent.

Twineedle deals damage and will strike twice (with 25 base move_power each time). It has a 20% chance of poisoning the target. Poison or Steel move_type Pokémon, those with the ability Immunity or those behind a Substitute cannot be poisoned.
Each strike of Twineedle is treated like a separate attack:
changes:
In Generations 1-2, Twineedle can poison Poison and Steel move_types.
In Generations 2-4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint.
In Generations 1-3, Twineedle ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute.
In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest.

effects: Wrap inflicts damage on the first turn then traps the omove_pponent, causing them to lose 1⁄16 of their maximum HP after each turn, for 4-5 turns. If the user holds a Grip Claw then it is always 5 turns.
changes: In Generations 1-4, Wrap has 85% move_accuracy. Its after-effects last for 2-5 turns instead of 4-5.
In Generation 1, Wrap simply inflicts its base move_power damage for 2-5 turns. While in effect, the target is unable to attack.
